What would he do differently if starting the project today? "I would lead with a strong user experience," he said. "When I released the first version of Drupal it attracted like-minded people, meaning other developers, and we got a bit of tunnel vision, it was for developers by developers. In the last 20 years the world has changed, the primary end user for a content management system like Drupal is no longer a developer but a marketer, typically a less technical person.

20 years of Drupal: Founder Dries Buytaert on API first, the end of breaking compatibility, and JavaScript bloat
Commercial involvement in open source is essential, says CMS boss

Drupal no longer deserves its "reputation of being a little hard to use...

Ha ..."a little" hard to use? :thinking:
"Truth by mistake" ... :laughing: It has become a pain.

I am nothing but scared for an upcoming customer project from D8 to D9, later in 2021... I also started to look for Drupal Commerce alternatives (thought that I would stick with Drupal for Shops, but it's more and more a disappointment and simply not working)
Is Backdrop that significantly easier, for the end user? I wonder.
Not sure about "significantly" @docwilmot ...I just hear people coming from D7 praising it, so I'm assuming we've been doing a good job :shrug:
...interesting that Dries in that article is saying that marketers are the main end users of Drupal ...I would say content editors are.

Is Backdrop that significantly easier, for the end user?

That might depend on who the "end user" is. The "marketer" might find D8/9 just fine, but I'd assume that these are familiar with all sorts of portals and social media. Compared to D7 several people (content editors) find Backdrop easier. Some site builders seem to struggle with the config and layout concepts, though.
But ... You can never make everyone happy, I guess.
One thing I'm convinced of: for site builders D8/9 is a pain. I'm aware, that wasn't the question. :wink:

docwilmot said:

Is Backdrop that significantly easier, for the end user? I wonder.

I think it depends on where the user is coming from, i.e., what systems they have been using, but my current viewpoint is that it is not.

...interesting that Dries in that article is saying that marketers are the main end users of Drupal ...I would say content editors are.

I think "marketers" implies content editors as the marketers are generally the ones doing the content editing. At least that's how I interpreted it.

Is Backdrop that significantly easier, for the end user?

I feel like it's getting there. A lot of work has already been done on the little things and it shows so great job to everyone for helping move BD in that direction :hug:

I also started to look for Drupal Commerce alternatives (thought that I would stick with Drupal for Shops, but it's more and more a disappointment and simply not working)

@mazze.ch my dream? Figure out a way to create a hybrid between Ubercart and Commerce. Developer AND user friendly.

@Phil Ward from what Drupal users tell me, Drupal Commerce 2.0 is already user friendly AND developer friendly. But new functions and bug fixes take way too long, the community might be simply too small, https://drupalcommerce.org has not been updated since autumn 2018.

https://www.theverge.com/2021/2/10/22276857/security-researcher-repository-exploit-apple-microsoft-vulnerability

Security researcher finds a way to run code on Apple, PayPal, and Microsoft’s systems
The companies were using code from the internet instead of their private programs.
I doubt this will impact the Backdrop community, however given its reliance on 3rd-party libraries, it might be worth noting.
Software supply chain will be the hot buzzword for 2021. Honestly, it should have been already after all the npm trojans over the last few years.

This is where organizations like https://tidelift.com/ may be useful. They offer services like ensuring security of a list of open source packages.

Tidelift | A managed open source subscription backed by creators and maintainers
Tidelift is a managed open source subscription, offering commercial support and maintenance for the open source dependencies used to build applications, backed by maintainers.
Back in the day, those were called "distributions." Companies like Red Hat, SuSE, and Canonical showed it was a profitable way to provide trusted open source packages.

The real problem is developers (web developers in particular) want the latest-greatest, just came out yesterday new hotness. And for managed distributions to keep up with that and maintain high quality support/security is not practical. Something has to give.

One of the main reasons organizations get disillusioned with Drupal is not unique to Drupal. It has to do with a lack of clearly defined goals.

TL;DR good stuff in the first few paragraphs though.

https://www.lullabot.com/articles/avoiding-drupal-disillusionment-drupal-long-term

Avoiding Drupal Disillusionment: Drupal for the Long-Term | Lullabot
Destroying everything and starting over every few years is enormously expensive and disruptive. Is it inevitable? We don't think so.

Drupal is the winner but only because the other CMS scores were so bad.
